sub_title: Erasmus+ International Master in Innovative Medicine (IMIM) Scholar | BSc Biomedicine | Immunology Enthusiast
summary:
An aspiring second-year master student from Indonesia who is fascinated by the intricate nature of immunology.

Currently, I am studying at University of Groningen and Uppsala University as part of the Erasmus+ Double Degree International Master in Innovative Medicine with a focus on future translational science.

education.field_of_study: MMS Molecular Medicine and Medical Research
MSc Molecular Medicine and Innovative Treatment (MMIT)

awards.title: Erasmus Mundus Joint Master Degree (EMJMD) Scholar of International Master in Innovative Medicine (IMIM)
awards.description: Out of 600 applicants around the world, I have been selected for for a full EMJMD partner country student scholarship. In addition, I also have been offered a place in the IMIM (International Master in Innovative Medicine) program, starting the first semester at the University of Groningen. The IMIM program is a two-year 120 ECTS, English-taught, master of excellence program, which focuses on the education of tomorrow’s leading translational biomedical researchers. IMIM is jointly organized by three European Top 100 Universities: the University of Groningen in the Netherlands, the Heidelberg University in Germany and Uppsala Universitet in Sweden.

projects.title: Effects of CDK 4/6 Inhibition on Pro-Inflammatory Phenotypes of Genotoxic Therapy-Induced Senescent Breast Cancer Cells
projects.description: Cellular senescence is defined as a state of cell cycle arrest that remains metabolically active by secreting a collection of inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, growth factors, and proteases, conjointly known as senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP). The detrimental consequences of long-term accumulation of genotoxic therapy-induced senescence have been reported to exert pro-tumorigenic effects and treatment-related toxicity in breast cancer patients mediated by SASP. FDA-approved CDK4/6 inhibitors (CDK4/6i) have been revealed to induce cellular senescence without pro-tumorigenic properties and are able to suppress the expression of proinflammatory SASP. However, the effects of CDK4/6i on genotoxic therapy-induced senescent breast cancer cells have not been well-defined. Here we show that the addition of CDK4/6i into a genotoxic therapy regimen is able to alter the characteristics and SASP expression of senescent breast cancer cells. Our findings observe that the combination of genotoxic therapy and CDK4/6i resulted in a lower percentage of senescent breast cancer cells that regained their proliferating feature, except for the radiation and abemaciclib group. Looking at the SASP expression, the presence of CDK4/6i in the doxorubicin-treated cancer cells induces a senescent state with lower expression of most key SASP factors while the presence of CDK4/6 escalated most key SASP expression levels in the radiation-induced senescent cells. Our findings highlight the different mechanisms of chemotherapy and radiotherapy in inducing cellular senescence as well as the different efficacy of CDK4/6i type, which eventually leads to different senescence characteristics.

contributors.headline: Erasmus+ International Master in Innovative Medicine (IMIM) Scholar | BSc Biomedicine | Immunology Enthusiast

projects.title: Cross-Reactivity Analysis between SARS-CoV-2 T Cell Epitopes with Epitopes from OPV, BCG, and MMR Vaccines Specific for Indonesian Population
projects.description:
Nearly all countries worldwide have been affected by the enormity of COVID-19 caused by SARS-CoV-2, including Indonesia. This pandemic has a variation in symptoms and the number of deaths among Indonesian COVID-19 patients, which could be explained by the nonspecific immunity provided by the cross-reactive epitopes from LAVs (BCG, OPV, and MMR). However, there is still a lack of base evidence showing the cross-reactivity between these LAVs and SARS-CoV-2 specific to the Indonesian population. Through in silico approach, the SARS-CoV-2 Wuhan-Hu-1 isolate T cell epitopes were predicted against HLA alleles specific to the Indonesian population. The generated epitopes were then compared with the OPV, BCG, and MMR sequence to identify similar patterns. The cross-reactive epitopes were further rechecked and inspected for their population coverage in Indonesia. Both BCG and MMR contain 15 and 7 strong binding cross-reactive epitopes specific to the Indonesian population, which have 2 to 4 amino acid substitutions compared with SARS-CoV-2 epitopes. Despite that, the cross-reactive epitopes are potentially able to induce either cross-reactive CD8+ or CD4+ T cells against SARS-CoV-2. Additionally, most cross-reactive epitopes have similar or higher population coverage than SARS-CoV-2 epitopes, ranging from 4.83% to 73.5%. In contrast, no cross-reactive epitopes were found from OPV specific to the Indonesian population, which may be due to the genome nature of poliovirus. Overall, these identified cross-reactive patterns may serve as a pillar for uncovering the full potential of beneficial cross-protection against SARS-CoV-2 and future
pandemics.

contributors.headline: Erasmus+ International Master in Innovative Medicine (IMIM) Scholar | BSc Biomedicine | Immunology Enthusiast

projects.title: In Vivo Wound Healing and Antimicrobial Evaluation of Silver Nanoparticles Incorporated Keratin-Pectin Hydrogels
projects.description: Keratin and pectin are naturally derived materials that have potential in wound treatment due to their biodegradability and biocompatibility compared to a classical dressing. Besides that, silver nanoparticles also gain research interest for wound healing due to their antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. This project aims to develop a wound dressing made from silver nanoparticles incorporated keratin-pectin hydrogels and evaluate the hydrogels' wound healing capability and antimicrobial activity. Twenty four mice were divided into three treatment groups, consisting of control (gauze), pectin 2% + AgNP, and keratin-pectin 1:2 (2%) + AgNP. The wounds were observed, and the wound size reduction was measured at allocated times. A wound swab was also performed to analyze the antimicrobial activity of the hydrogels. Both pectin AgNP and keratin-pectin AgNP groups demonstrated superior wound healing properties macroscopically. However, the pectin AgNP group had a higher wound size reduction percentage than the keratin-pectin AgNP group on day 6 (p <0.05). There was no significant difference in wound size reduction percentage found between each group on days 3 and 9. Due to detached wound dressings during the study, the antimicrobial evaluation was also inconclusive. Further histology study is suggested to uncover more wound healing potential of silver nanoparticles incorporated keratin-pectin hydrogels.

profile_positions.description:
As a Student Ambassador of Surplus, I helped them to contribute in achieving Sustainable Development Goals, including zero hunger, responsible consumption and production, and climate action. Some of the ways to achieve those values as follows: 
- Educate students on my university about Surplus’s vision and mission
- Increase brand awareness of Surplus to students in my university by promoting it through my social media
- Responsible in increasing the number of people using Surplus food rescue app
- Make a report every month about my activities, achievements, insights, and recommendations to Surplus and so on.
profile_positions.title: Student Ambassador of Surplus Indonesia
